models.example: A project spans five teams. Meetings and handoffs consume more time than actual build work. Delivery slows despite high effort.
models.tryThis: Reduce dependencies and define clear interfaces. Replace recurring meetings with async updates.

models.title: Compound Growth
models.principle: Growth that accelerates because gains build on prior gains.
models.coreConcept: Compounding makes small, consistent improvements powerful over time. The key drivers are rate, time, and reinvestment of gains.
models.example: A product grows users by 2 percent per week. The base expands, so each week adds more users than the last. Over time, growth accelerates.
models.tryThis: Track growth rate and doubling time. Improve one lever that moves the rate by even a small amount.

models.title: Compound Interest
models.principle: Interest earned on both principal and accumulated interest.
models.coreConcept: Compounding rewards time more than timing. Early contributions and consistent growth have outsized impact on long-term outcomes.
models.example: An investor saves $200 per month at 7 percent annual return. The first years grow slowly, but later years add more than the contributions. Compounding does the heavy lifting.
models.tryThis: Model different rates and time horizons. Automate contributions and reinvest gains.

models.title: Continuous Improvement
models.principle: Ongoing, incremental enhancements to processes and products.
models.coreConcept: Small, frequent improvements accumulate into major performance gains. It relies on feedback loops, measurement, and a culture of iteration.
models.example: A team ships small improvements every week. Each change alone is modest, but the cumulative effect is large. Quality and speed both rise over time.
models.tryThis: Pick one small improvement each week. Review results in retros and stack the wins.

models.title: Core Competency
models.principle: A distinctive capability that provides strategic advantage.
models.coreConcept: Core competencies are valuable, rare, and difficult to imitate. They enable access to multiple markets and underpin long-term differentiation.
models.example: A company excels at logistics. It outsources areas where it is average and doubles down on its advantage. The competency becomes a moat.
models.tryThis: Identify your one or two true strengths. Invest there and deprioritize the rest.

models.title: Customer Development
models.principle: A structured process to discover and validate customer needs before scaling.
models.coreConcept: Customer development emphasizes interviews, experiments, and iterative learning. It reduces risk by validating problems and solutions early.
models.example: A startup interviews 20 target users before building. The conversations reveal a different primary pain point. The product pivots early and avoids wasted build.
models.tryThis: Schedule weekly customer interviews. Turn insights into a ranked list of assumptions to test.

models.title: Customer Needs
models.principle: Identify the underlying needs customers are trying to satisfy, not just their stated requests.
models.coreConcept: Customers often describe solutions rather than problems. Understanding the job-to-be-done reveals the real constraints and value drivers, guiding better product decisions.
models.example: A team builds a feature based on internal assumptions. Real users want faster setup instead. Shifting to the true need improves adoption.
models.tryThis: Write the top three user jobs-to-be-done. Validate each with real user quotes.

models.title: Decision Fatigue
models.principle: Decision quality declines after making too many choices in a row.
models.coreConcept: Cognitive resources are finite. As they deplete, people default to the status quo, impulsive choices, or avoid decisions altogether.
models.example: A leader makes dozens of decisions in the morning. By afternoon, they delay a high-stakes choice and default to the safest option. Quality drops as mental energy fades.
models.tryThis: Schedule important decisions early. Set defaults for low-stakes choices.

models.title: Desirable Difficulties
models.principle: Learning improves when it is effortful but achievable.
models.coreConcept: Struggle signals deeper processing: spacing, retrieval practice, and varied contexts create stronger memory than easy repetition.
models.example: A student practices with spaced repetition and mixed problems. Learning feels harder but retention improves. Tests reveal deeper understanding.
models.tryThis: Introduce spacing or interleaving into practice. Track performance over time, not just immediate ease.

models.title: Division of Labor
models.principle: Specialization boosts efficiency by letting people focus on narrower tasks.
models.coreConcept: Specialization increases speed and quality but adds coordination cost. The optimal split balances specialization with handoff friction.
models.example: In a factory, workers specialize in specific steps. Output increases because each person becomes faster and more accurate. Coordination keeps the system flowing.
models.tryThis: Break work into discrete steps and assign clear ownership. Monitor handoffs for delays.

models.title: Ego Depletion
models.principle: Self‑control and focus weaken after sustained mental effort.
models.coreConcept: When willpower is taxed, people are more likely to procrastinate or choose short‑term rewards. Environment design and routines can mitigate this.
models.example: After a day of tough decisions, a manager skips the gym. Their willpower is lower and temptations feel stronger. Self-control fades with exhaustion.
models.tryThis: Remove temptations from the environment. Reserve demanding tasks for when energy is high.

models.title: Empathy
models.principle: Understanding others’ feelings and perspectives improves decisions and relationships.
models.coreConcept: Empathy has cognitive (understanding) and affective (feeling) components. It reduces conflict and improves product decisions by aligning with real user experience.
models.example: A designer shadows users completing onboarding. They notice confusion at a specific step. Fixing it increases activation.
models.tryThis: Observe users directly. Summarize what they feel, think, and do at each step.

models.title: Epistemic Humility
models.principle: Recognize the limits of your knowledge and update beliefs when new evidence appears.
models.coreConcept: Humility about uncertainty reduces overconfidence, invites better questions, and improves learning. It is a cornerstone of good judgment.
models.example: A leader states their confidence level before a decision. The team shares counterevidence and updates the plan. The final choice is stronger.
models.tryThis: Add a confidence score to key decisions. Revisit and update it after results.

models.title: Escalation of Commitment
models.principle: People keep investing in failing paths because of sunk costs and ego.
models.coreConcept: When time, money, or reputation are already invested, people rationalize continued investment to avoid admitting a loss.
models.example: A project misses milestones but keeps getting funding. The team focuses on past investment instead of future value. Losses compound as commitment grows.
models.tryThis: Define exit criteria before starting. Review progress against those criteria on a fixed cadence.

models.title: First Impressions
models.principle: Early judgments disproportionately shape later perceptions.
models.coreConcept: The primacy effect makes initial experiences “sticky.” This influences hiring, onboarding, and product adoption.
models.example: A user opens an app and sees a cluttered dashboard. They assume the product is complex and leave. A clearer first screen would have kept them.
models.tryThis: Review the first 30 seconds of use. Remove friction and highlight the primary value.

models.title: Homeostasis
models.principle: Systems naturally resist change to maintain stability.
models.coreConcept: Feedback loops push systems toward a set point. Change often triggers counter‑forces that restore the prior state.
models.example: The body regulates temperature when it gets too hot or cold. Small adjustments restore balance. The system resists sudden change.
models.tryThis: Identify the balancing forces in your system. Expect resistance and plan gradual shifts.

models.title: Incremental Innovation
models.principle: Small, continuous improvements can produce large gains over time.
models.coreConcept: Incremental innovation exploits existing capabilities and compounds learning. It is lower risk than radical innovation and often more reliable.
models.example: A product team makes small improvements to onboarding each release. Activation climbs steadily without a single big redesign. Users feel the product is getting better each month.
models.tryThis: Pick one small improvement per release. Measure its effect before moving on.

models.title: Innovation
models.principle: Creating new value by combining novelty with usefulness.
models.coreConcept: Innovation can be technological, process, or business‑model driven. It requires exploration, experimentation, and a path to adoption.
models.example: A team combines an existing technology with a new distribution channel. The new product unlocks a market that did not exist before. Adoption grows rapidly because it solves a real gap.
models.tryThis: Look for new combinations of tech, channel, and customer need. Prototype the smallest test.

models.title: Law of Unintended Consequences
models.principle: Interventions in complex systems often produce unexpected outcomes.
models.coreConcept: Because systems are interconnected, changes create secondary and tertiary effects. Small policy tweaks can cause large behavioral shifts.
models.example: A company pays a bonus for resolved tickets. Agents rush to close tickets, leaving issues unresolved. Customer satisfaction drops.
models.tryThis: Before launching a policy, list possible gaming behaviors. Add guardrails and monitor leading indicators.

models.title: Maintenance
models.principle: Sustained effort is required to keep systems reliable and healthy.
models.coreConcept: All systems degrade without upkeep. Maintenance prevents hidden costs like downtime, errors, and technical debt.
models.example: A system runs well at launch but receives no upkeep. Over time, small issues accumulate and cause outages. Maintenance prevents compounding failures.
models.tryThis: Schedule recurring maintenance time. Track and fix the top recurring issues.

models.title: Marginal Analysis
models.principle: Decisions should be based on the next unit of cost and benefit, not totals.
models.coreConcept: At the margin, the best choice is where incremental benefit equals incremental cost. This avoids over‑investment in low‑return areas.
models.example: A team considers adding another support rep. The first hire reduces response time significantly, but the next yields only a small gain. Marginal benefit falls as capacity grows.
models.tryThis: Estimate the incremental benefit and cost of each added unit. Stop when marginal benefit drops below marginal cost.

models.title: Murphy's Law
models.principle: If something can go wrong, it eventually will.
models.coreConcept: Complex systems have many failure points. Planning for failure (redundancy, monitoring, rollback) reduces impact.
models.example: A launch plan assumes every dependency will be ready. One supplier is late and the whole release slips. Contingency planning would have reduced the impact.
models.tryThis: List the most likely failure points. Add buffers and backups for each.

models.title: Obsolescence
models.principle: Products, skills, and systems lose value as technology or context changes.
models.coreConcept: Obsolescence can be planned, technological, or market‑driven. It creates upgrade cycles and strategic replacement decisions.
models.example: A desktop app becomes obsolete as users shift to mobile‑first workflows. This illustrates Obsolescence: Products, skills, and systems lose value as technology or context changes. In practice, Obsolescence can be planned, technological, or market‑driven.
models.tryThis: Identify the signals that would make your product or process obsolete and plan contingencies. Test a small change in a low-risk segment and measure the impact.

models.title: Optimization
models.principle: Improving a system toward a defined objective.
models.coreConcept: Optimization can create local maxima and unintended trade‑offs. The objective function must align with true goals.
models.example: A team optimizes click‑through rates but harms long‑term retention by promoting low‑quality content. This illustrates Optimization: Improving a system toward a defined objective. In practice, Optimization can create local maxima and unintended trade‑offs.
models.tryThis: Define the primary objective and add guardrail metrics to prevent harmful optimization. Write the steps, find the leverage point, and review after one cycle.

models.title: Pattern Recognition
models.principle: The ability to detect regularities and predict outcomes from them.
models.coreConcept: Pattern recognition speeds decisions but can also create false positives. It improves with feedback and reflection.
models.example: A doctor recognizes a rare condition because the symptom pattern matches prior cases. This illustrates Pattern Recognition: The ability to detect regularities and predict outcomes from them. In practice, Pattern recognition speeds decisions but can also create false positives.
models.tryThis: Keep a decision journal to validate which patterns are reliable and which are noise. Notice when this pattern shows up today and pause before acting.

models.title: Platform Business Model
models.principle: A model that enables interactions between two or more participant groups.
models.coreConcept: Platforms create value by reducing friction between sides and leveraging network effects. Success depends on solving the chicken‑and‑egg problem.
models.example: A marketplace connects buyers and sellers, growing in value as each side increases. This illustrates Platform Business Model: A model that enables interactions between two or more participant groups. In practice, Platforms create value by reducing friction between sides and leveraging network effects.
models.tryThis: Seed one side with incentives or a niche beachhead before scaling. Test a small change in a low-risk segment and measure the impact.

models.title: Portfolio Approach
models.principle: Diversify across multiple bets to manage risk and capture upside.
models.coreConcept: A portfolio balances high‑risk/high‑reward initiatives with stable, lower‑risk ones. It reduces dependence on any single outcome.
models.example: A product org invests in one radical innovation, several incremental improvements, and a core maintenance stream. This illustrates Portfolio Approach: Diversify across multiple bets to manage risk and capture upside. In practice, A portfolio balances high‑risk/high‑reward initiatives with stable, lower‑risk ones.
models.tryThis: Categorize initiatives by risk/return and ensure the mix matches your strategy. Write the steps, find the leverage point, and review after one cycle.

models.title: Positive Feedback Loop
models.principle: Outputs reinforce inputs, creating accelerating growth or decline.
models.coreConcept: Positive feedback loops can drive viral growth, market lock‑in, or runaway failure. They are powerful but unstable without constraints.
models.example: Word‑of‑mouth drives more users, which creates more content, which attracts even more users. This illustrates Positive Feedback Loop: Outputs reinforce inputs, creating accelerating growth or decline. In practice, Positive feedback loops can drive viral growth, market lock‑in, or runaway failure.
models.tryThis: Identify one reinforcing loop in your product and design to amplify it safely. Write the steps, find the leverage point, and review after one cycle.

models.title: Power Law Distribution
models.principle: A small number of items account for a large share of the outcome.
models.coreConcept: Power laws produce heavy tails and extreme winners. Averages can be misleading; the top few often dominate.
models.example: A tiny fraction of customers drives most revenue; most users contribute little. This illustrates Power Law Distribution: A small number of items account for a large share of the outcome. In practice, Power laws produce heavy tails and extreme winners.
models.tryThis: Plot your metrics on a log scale to see if a power law is present. Write the steps, find the leverage point, and review after one cycle.

models.title: Price Discovery
models.principle: The process by which markets find the price that balances supply and demand.
models.coreConcept: Prices emerge through bidding, negotiation, and experimentation. Good price discovery reduces volatility and improves allocation.
models.example: An auction platform reveals a true market price as bidders compete. This illustrates Price Discovery: The process by which markets find the price that balances supply and demand. In practice, Prices emerge through bidding, negotiation, and experimentation.
models.tryThis: Run structured price tests or auctions to learn willingness to pay. Test a small change in a low-risk segment and measure the impact.

models.title: Prior Probability
models.principle: The base rate of an event before considering new evidence.
models.coreConcept: Bayesian reasoning starts with prior probability and updates with new data. Ignoring priors leads to overreaction to weak evidence.
models.example: A rare disease is unlikely even with one positive test; the base rate matters. This illustrates Prior Probability: The base rate of an event before considering new evidence. In practice, Bayesian reasoning starts with prior probability and updates with new data.
models.tryThis: Write the base rate before analyzing evidence, then update explicitly. Notice when this pattern shows up today and pause before acting.

models.title: Product Lifecycle
models.principle: Products move through introduction, growth, maturity, and decline.
models.coreConcept: Each stage calls for different strategies: awareness in growth, efficiency in maturity, and reinvention or harvesting in decline.
models.example: A mature app shifts from acquisition to retention and pricing optimization. This illustrates Product Lifecycle: Products move through introduction, growth, maturity, and decline. In practice, Each stage calls for different strategies: awareness in growth, efficiency in maturity, and reinvention or harvesting in decline.
models.tryThis: Identify your product’s stage and align goals and metrics to that stage. Test a small change in a low-risk segment and measure the impact.

models.title: Projection Bias
models.principle: We overestimate how much our future preferences will match our current state.
models.coreConcept: People make decisions while hungry, tired, or excited and misjudge how they will feel later, leading to regret.
models.example: Someone orders too much food while hungry and regrets it later. This illustrates Projection Bias: We overestimate how much our future preferences will match our current state. In practice, People make decisions while hungry, tired, or excited and misjudge how they will feel later, leading to regret.
models.tryThis: Delay irreversible decisions until your state changes, or ask a neutral party for input. Notice when this pattern shows up today and pause before acting.

models.title: Prospect Theory
models.principle: Losses feel larger than gains, and decisions depend on reference points.
models.coreConcept: People are risk‑averse for gains and risk‑seeking for losses. Framing changes choices even when outcomes are equivalent.
models.example: A discount framed as “avoid a $50 loss” converts better than “save $50.”. This illustrates Prospect Theory: Losses feel larger than gains, and decisions depend on reference points.
models.tryThis: Test alternative frames for the same choice to see how behavior shifts. Notice when this pattern shows up today and pause before acting.

models.title: Psychological Ownership
models.principle: When people feel something is “theirs,” they value and protect it more.
models.coreConcept: Ownership grows with control, investment, and personalization. It increases engagement and retention.
models.example: Users who customize a dashboard are more likely to return and defend the product. This illustrates Psychological Ownership: When people feel something is “theirs,” they value and protect it more. In practice, Ownership grows with control, investment, and personalization.
models.tryThis: Add lightweight customization so users can make the product feel personal. Notice when this pattern shows up today and pause before acting.

models.title: 10,000 Hour Rule
models.principle: Mastery comes from many hours of deliberate practice, not talent alone.
models.coreConcept: Skill grows through focused repetition with feedback; hours are a proxy for quality practice, not a guarantee. The rule highlights long time horizons.
models.example: A designer improves faster by reviewing every project with a mentor rather than just logging hours. This illustrates 10,000 Hour Rule: Mastery comes from many hours of deliberate practice, not talent alone. In practice, Skill grows through focused repetition with feedback; hours are a proxy for quality practice, not a guarantee.
models.tryThis: Track weekly deliberate practice time and add feedback loops. Notice when this pattern shows up today and pause before acting.

models.title: Abstraction
models.principle: Hide unnecessary details to focus on essential structure.
models.coreConcept: Abstraction reduces complexity and enables transfer across contexts. The risk is losing important nuance.
models.example: Treating users as segments simplifies planning but can miss edge cases. This illustrates Abstraction: Hide unnecessary details to focus on essential structure. In practice, Abstraction reduces complexity and enables transfer across contexts.
models.tryThis: State the abstraction you are using and list what it ignores. Write the steps, find the leverage point, and review after one cycle.
related: The Map is Not the Territory

models.title: Accountability
models.principle: Clear ownership improves follow-through and results.
models.coreConcept: When responsibilities and outcomes are explicit, incentives align and coordination improves. Without accountability, diffusion of responsibility grows.
models.example: A team assigns a single owner to a launch, reducing last-minute confusion. This illustrates Accountability: Clear ownership improves follow-through and results. In practice, When responsibilities and outcomes are explicit, incentives align and coordination improves.
models.tryThis: For each deliverable, name one accountable owner and one measurable outcome. Notice when this pattern shows up today and pause before acting.

models.title: Active Recall
models.principle: Retrieval strengthens memory more than re-reading.
models.coreConcept: Testing yourself forces reconstruction and reveals gaps. It is a high-effort, high-yield learning method.
models.example: Flashcards outperform highlight-and-reread for long-term retention. This illustrates Active Recall: Retrieval strengthens memory more than re-reading. In practice, Testing yourself forces reconstruction and reveals gaps.
models.tryThis: End each study session with a blank-page recall of key ideas. Notice when this pattern shows up today and pause before acting.

models.title: Actor-Observer Bias
models.principle: We attribute our actions to situation and others' actions to character.
models.coreConcept: Context feels vivid for ourselves but invisible for others, leading to unfair judgments. It can damage trust in teams.
models.example: You explain your missed deadline by workload but label a peer as careless. This illustrates Actor-Observer Bias: We attribute our actions to situation and others' actions to character. In practice, Context feels vivid for ourselves but invisible for others, leading to unfair judgments.
models.tryThis: Ask what situational factors could explain the other person's behavior. Notice when this pattern shows up today and pause before acting.

models.title: Addition by Subtraction
models.principle: Removing elements can improve outcomes more than adding new ones.
models.coreConcept: Complexity hides performance and increases maintenance. Subtraction reveals the core value and reduces cognitive load.
models.example: Cutting a feature increases activation by making the flow simpler. This illustrates Addition by Subtraction: Removing elements can improve outcomes more than adding new ones. In practice, Complexity hides performance and increases maintenance.
models.tryThis: Identify one step or feature to remove and measure the effect. Write the steps, find the leverage point, and review after one cycle.

models.title: Adoption Barriers
models.principle: Friction and risk slow or prevent adoption of new products or behaviors.
models.coreConcept: Barriers include switching costs, learning effort, uncertainty, and social resistance. Lowering barriers accelerates adoption.
models.example: A B2B tool fails because migration takes weeks. This illustrates Adoption Barriers: Friction and risk slow or prevent adoption of new products or behaviors. In practice, Barriers include switching costs, learning effort, uncertainty, and social resistance.
models.tryThis: Map the top three barriers and design one removal experiment. Test a small change in a low-risk segment and measure the impact.

models.title: Affective Forecasting
models.principle: We mispredict how future events will feel.
models.coreConcept: People overestimate intensity and duration of emotions and ignore adaptation. This leads to poor decisions based on imagined feelings.
models.example: A team over-prioritizes a feature because they expect it to delight users for months. This illustrates Affective Forecasting: We mispredict how future events will feel. In practice, People overestimate intensity and duration of emotions and ignore adaptation.
models.tryThis: Use data from past experiences to recalibrate emotional predictions. Notice when this pattern shows up today and pause before acting.

models.title: Agency
models.principle: Belief in your ability to influence outcomes drives motivation.
models.coreConcept: High agency increases persistence and learning; low agency leads to passivity. Perceived control often matters as much as actual control.
models.example: A coach reframes setbacks as controllable, improving player effort. This illustrates Agency: Belief in your ability to influence outcomes drives motivation. In practice, High agency increases persistence and learning; low agency leads to passivity.
models.tryThis: Identify one lever you control in a stalled project and act on it. Notice when this pattern shows up today and pause before acting.

models.title: Agency Costs
models.principle: Delegation creates costs when incentives are misaligned.
models.coreConcept: Monitoring, bonding, and residual loss are the price of delegation. Reducing agency costs requires better incentives and transparency.
models.example: A sales team optimizes for short-term commission at the expense of retention. This illustrates Agency Costs: Delegation creates costs when incentives are misaligned. In practice, Monitoring, bonding, and residual loss are the price of delegation.
models.tryThis: Audit incentives for roles where outcomes and rewards differ. Test a small change in a low-risk segment and measure the impact.

models.title: Agency Problem
models.principle: Delegation creates conflicts between the decision maker and the owner of outcomes.
models.coreConcept: Agents may pursue their own goals unless aligned and monitored. The problem shows up in governance, management, and platforms.
models.example: A manager ships risky changes to hit a bonus, harming long-term reliability. This illustrates Agency Problem: Delegation creates conflicts between the decision maker and the owner of outcomes. In practice, Agents may pursue their own goals unless aligned and monitored.
models.tryThis: Align incentives and define clear metrics for delegated decisions. Test a small change in a low-risk segment and measure the impact.

models.title: Alignment
models.principle: Systems work when goals, incentives, and actions point in the same direction.
models.coreConcept: Misalignment produces wasted effort, gaming, and unintended outcomes. Alignment requires shared metrics and feedback.
models.example: Marketing optimizes leads while sales optimizes revenue, creating poor handoffs. This illustrates Alignment: Systems work when goals, incentives, and actions point in the same direction. In practice, Misalignment produces wasted effort, gaming, and unintended outcomes.
models.tryThis: Check if every team metric rolls up to the same outcome. Test a small change in a low-risk segment and measure the impact.

models.title: All Models Are Wrong
models.principle: Models are simplifications; they are useful, not literal truth.
models.coreConcept: Any model omits reality, so use them as tools and update when they fail. The danger is mistaking the model for the world.
models.example: A retention model misses a new channel and under-forecasts growth. This illustrates All Models Are Wrong: Models are simplifications; they are useful, not literal truth. In practice, Any model omits reality, so use them as tools and update when they fail.
models.tryThis: List the main assumptions in your model and test the riskiest one. Write the steps, find the leverage point, and review after one cycle.
related: The Map is Not the Territory

models.title: Appeal to Authority
models.principle: A claim is treated as true because an authority says it.
models.coreConcept: Expertise matters, but authority can be misplaced or outside its domain. Arguments should stand on evidence, not status.
models.example: A strategy is adopted because a famous CEO endorsed it, despite poor fit. This illustrates Appeal to Authority: A claim is treated as true because an authority says it. In practice, Expertise matters, but authority can be misplaced or outside its domain.
models.tryThis: Separate the claim from the speaker and evaluate the evidence. Notice when this pattern shows up today and pause before acting.

models.title: Arms Race
models.principle: Competitors escalate capabilities, raising costs for everyone.
models.coreConcept: When each side must match the other, the race can erode profits and increase risk. It often ends in regulation or consolidation.
models.example: Two platforms spend heavily on subsidies just to keep share. This illustrates Arms Race: Competitors escalate capabilities, raising costs for everyone. In practice, When each side must match the other, the race can erode profits and increase risk.
models.tryThis: Identify whether you are in an arms race and explore a different basis of competition. Test a small change in a low-risk segment and measure the impact.

models.title: Assumption of Positive Intent
models.principle: Start by assuming others mean well to improve communication.
models.coreConcept: This reduces defensiveness and opens curiosity, especially under ambiguity. It does not excuse bad behavior but changes how you respond.
models.example: Interpreting a short reply as busy rather than rude keeps the conversation constructive. This illustrates Assumption of Positive Intent: Start by assuming others mean well to improve communication. In practice, This reduces defensiveness and opens curiosity, especially under ambiguity.
models.tryThis: Before responding, restate the likely positive intent behind the message. Notice when this pattern shows up today and pause before acting.

models.title: Asymmetric Competition
models.principle: Opponents with different strengths and goals require different strategies.
models.coreConcept: Competing directly on the same axis favors the incumbent. Asymmetry means you should compete where they are weak or uninterested.
